abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Purpose</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Coding mutations in the <jats:italic>Transthyretin</jats:italic> (<jats:italic>TTR</jats:italic>) gene cause a hereditary form of amyloidosis characterized by a complex genotype-phenotype correlation with limited information regarding differences among worldwide populations.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>We compared 676 diverse individuals carrying <jats:italic>TTR</jats:italic> amyloidogenic mutations (rs138065384, Phe44Leu; rs730881165, Ala81Thr; rs121918074, His90Asn; rs76992529, Val122Ile) to 12,430 non-carriers matched by age, sex, and genetically-inferred ancestry to assess their clinical presentations across 1,693 outcomes derived from electronic health records in UK biobank.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>In individuals of African descent (AFR), Val122Ile mutation was linked to multiple outcomes related to the circulatory system (fold-enrichment = 2.96, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.002) with the strongest associations being cardiac congenital anomalies (phecode 747.1, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.003), endocarditis (phecode 420.3, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.006), and cardiomyopathy (phecode 425, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.007). In individuals of Central-South Asian descent (CSA), His90Asn mutation was associated with dermatologic outcomes (fold-enrichment = 28, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.001). The same <jats:italic>TTR</jats:italic> mutation was linked to neoplasms in European-descent individuals (EUR, fold-enrichment = 3.09, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.003). In EUR, Ala81Thr showed multiple associations with respiratory outcomes related (fold-enrichment = 3.61, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.002), but the strongest association was with atrioventricular block (phecode 426.2, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 2.81 × 10<jats:sup>− 4</jats:sup>). Additionally, the same mutation in East Asians (EAS) showed associations with endocrine-metabolic traits (fold-enrichment = 4.47, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.003). In the cross-ancestry meta-analysis, Val122Ile mutation was associated with peripheral nerve disorders (phecode 351, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.004) in addition to cardiac congenital anomalies (fold-enrichment = 6.94, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.003).</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Overall, these findings highlight that <jats:italic>TTR</jats:italic> amyloidogenic mutations present ancestry-specific and ancestry-convergent associations related to a range of health domains. This supports the need to increase awareness regarding the range of outcomes associated with <jats:italic>TTR</jats:italic> mutations across worldwide populations to reduce misdiagnosis and delayed diagnosis of TTR-related amyloidosis.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: This study was approved under protocol 227/20 by the Comitato Etico Indipendente, Fondazione Policlinico Tor Vergata—Rome, Italy. This research was performed using the UKB Resource under the application 58146.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: ADL received a grant from Pfizer. The other authors declare that they have no competing interests.

publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
